pros:
Helio is one of the best companies to work for in the industry. I have experience working at several other companies in healthcare, and I know for a fact that none of them are better than here. The work environment is just phenomenal. Even though the workload can feel a mile high at times, everyone in the office stays upbeat and positive and we work together to get it done. Management is great in that regard – they don’t hire people with bad attitudes.

There’s no toxicity. No cutthroat competitiveness. No pettiness. No drama. Nothing you’d expect to find at such a large, established company. I was blown away when I first got hired on and I kept waiting for the “other shoe to drop”, so to speak. But it’s been over 4 years now and it’s exactly as healthy and supportive of an environment as it’s been since day 1.

I can’t imagine working anywhere else. If all goes according to plan, I’ll be retiring from Helio in about 35 years.
cons: The only thing I can say is that my opinions of the company are based solely on my own experience here. I would guess that other employees have similar experiences/perspectives, but I can’t guarantee it and I don’t want to speak for anyone but myself. And as far as any cons that I’ve experienced during my time at Helio, I don’t believe there are any.

pros: You will Get to help patients

pros: Working here has been one of the most rewarding experiences I could have ever asked for. I start my day knowing the work I carry out each day has a direct impact on the lives of many different people. My colleagues are friendly and supportive and driven and generally all-round inspiring people, whom I really enjoy working with. I have worked at a lot of different mental health service providers, but this one feels the most right. Here, I have a strong sense of pride and at least for the foreseeable future, cannot imagine working anywhere else.
cons: It is evident in other reviews that this place definitely has had its ups and downs. The good news is these times are now over, thanks in part to the work senior management did by working hard to address any issues head on. Communication is more transparent than ever before. It would have an easy and maybe even understandable to tighten the reins on employees, but instead a culture of support and personal development has been put in place.

review_title: A positive experience from the word go
pros: From the moment I went into my interview, to accepting a position, to my where I am currently with the company, I’ve had nothing but a positive experience here! Everyone on the staff is welcoming and friendly. You get recognition by management for great work and immediate assistance if you’re struggling with anything. Everyone is there to help each other out and if someone needs help in one department, you can bet it’s going to be a collective effort to get the problem solved. Even though the company has several different departments we all make up ONE cohesive unit as a company, and that’s why teamwork is not only expected within a department, but throughout the entire organization. The benefits and pay are well within reason and I’ve never not received a pay increase after a review... plus, if you ever need time off they’re very accommodating. I personally haven’t had a single request rejected since I started (although to be fair, I always give ample heads up). All in all, I would recommend anyone looking for a job to apply here… you never know, it could be the perfect fit!
cons: Every company has its ups and downs but if you work together you can accomplish anything! There are cons to working here to be sure, but it’s mostly because we are so busy. That being said, when everyone is on their A game and we have all the people we need, we’ve never had issues pulling through.

pros: Patients are the only pro
cons: Everything. Condescending & unorganized management

pros: One of the best parts of this company is how easy it is to believe in what we do. Not only am I proud to work here, but I’m honored. Every day I come to work, I know that what I’m doing makes a difference. And everyone else who works here knows that, too. We’re all happy to be here, and I can feel the happy energy every morning I walk into work. This job showed me my mission and I’m going to spend the rest of my life trying to help make sure people get the help they deserve. Helio is just the first step in that process.

Management AKA Leadership changes the rules every week. Such as where patients can and can't go in the building. Your job is enforcing the new rules and taking the heat of the backlash because patients are vulnerable and emotional.
Leadership's attitude is "that's a you problem. This place gives you everything you need" and they do not back down from that detatched attitude. Everything wrong is the CAs and the Nurses' fault. We complain too much, we're all jaded and grouchy, we aren't staffed because of too many call-ins.

All new employees get one or two days of orientation with slide shows, then they throw you onto the floor with no proper training in the database program, the medical charts, the MSFT Teams program..... you have to learn every little thing from whoever's around and knows how to do it

pros:
- They do go above and beyond to try their best to keep staff by offering a lot of incentives and swag. 
- Many of the supervisors are wonderful clinicians with great knowledge to offer but limited time to teach. 
- Working in the SUD/MH field can be challenging but is also beautiful and rewarding.
- Great tech. No out of data systems. 
- Beautiful building (located in dicey area)
cons:
THE ***NEW EMPLOYEE*** PARKING LOT IS 3 MILES FROM THE BUILDING!!! There is a guy they pay to drive employees back and forth but he is not always there. I end up walking almost every other day. It's approx. 6-7 minute walk down N. Salina Street under the bridge. Every counselor is expected to do one late night a week until 8pm as well. 

Flashy swag and incentives are offered in lieu of supporting employees and making necessary changes to better serve the community. Self-care is a must in a community clinic of this size because you see patients back to back all day long, no time to use the bathroom, lunch breaks are spent catching up on notes in front of the computer, case load size is between 50-80. There is no cap on case loads and you do not have the option of saying no if you don't feel comfortable taking someone. Everyone must take a group, even if you do not feel comfortable or aren't good at running groups, there are no guidelines created so you make up the material as you go along. Leadership makes decisions from the top down for clinicians but many of them have never held a clinical role themselves or functioned at the same capacity. You are expected to complete multiple reoccurring assessments with patients all the times. Patients become angry because you spend so much time asking questions, it's not therapy. We are just data collectors.

pros: The learning experience you will gain from Helio is like no other.  You will learn how NOT to treat a population that is already stigmatized by the general public.  You will learn what poor supervision looks like.  You will learn what burnout feels like.  You will get to experience what it is like to be prayed upon by white privilege and if your lucky you may even get groped and a pay raise. By working for Helio you will learn what its like to monopolize an industry and how to slam the weak to the floor.
cons: Its interesting how the truthful reviews get pushed to the bottom and the two line positive ones are upfront. Helio does not have any ethics and follows no moral compass.  If you read over the other reviews, you are able to see what I am talking about.  You can over hear management soliciting employees to leave positive reviews on places like this.  The positive reviews left on here sound like scripted responses by upper management and HR gives a scripted response as well.  There is no detail to individuals.   There was a panic in the air when realistic reviews started to surface.  Glassdoor does a great job of allowing truthful reviews to remain and encourages other to speak out.  They are damaging both clients and professionals.  Their management is in place out of convenience and not out of talent.   There is no teamwork.  You will be stabbed in the back before you even know it.  As you are bleeding out they will ask you to resign instead of firing you to save them from paying unemployment. Supervision does not happen and there are no ways for you to process your caseload, transference issues or vicarious trauma.  Helio wonders why their employee retention rate is so low?  The higher management is making six figures and the front line staff will be lucky to make 30K a year.  This company s ruled by white privilege and continues to oppress people trying to make a living.  There are so many different opportunities in CNY don't be tarnished by Helio.
